pros: The company has various challenges and raffles to boost employee moral and create fun working enviornment. Jobs at this facility truly care and try their best to help the community along side mental health services. There are ways to grow and move up throughout organization. Managment is very fair and they are understanding. There are ways the company rewards your hard work and ethics with things put in place like the 365 award and shout outs from clients resulting in jackets, shirts, and other Gracepoint goodies. Working for this company is a blessing and I see myself retiring here.
cons: Not really any I can think of at the moment.

review_title: Just ok at the childrens facility (Evening shift)
job_title: BHT-behavioral Health Tech in Tampa, FL
pros: -Can be creative in engagements with patients -You usually see the same kids, so you build a bond with them. -summer is slower, so you can rest a little with a smaller census. -There are some great kids who are very sweet -You can grow here with the right degree. Many techs who are in school have moved up to care managers after graduation. You'll probably have a job waiting for you if you're in school for nursing or therapy.
cons: -Would be nice if there were some color or pictures on the walls for a happy environment. -No therapist for evening. You have to be the one to calm the patient down. -very stressful, especially when there's 25 plus kids. They'll split kids on day shift but evening they're stuck in the small dining room. -Sometimes staff has not payed attention to the kids like they're supposed to. -staff has been hit or miss -be prepared to find out bad news about patients outside the facility. It will affect you. -You need to have alot of patience -be prepared for psychotic, aggressive, and patients who are strange or manipulative.

pros: You will gain a lot of experience that will prepare you for practically any social service job. They paid under the median but have made efforts to make their pay competitive in the field since then. Do not work here longer than a year. It's easy to get stuck.
cons: Fast-paced environment but maybe too fast. Consistently understaffed. Specifically for the CSU, management is terrible. Other departments like Homeless Services or Forensics do not have same problem.

pros: Good job for gaining initial experience in field. PRN pros are being able to create your own schedule as well as work as many or as little hours as you would like.
cons: No pay increases or yearly bonuses

pros: Never it’s not worth it
cons: Your life becomes hell on earth

review_title: Great entry into mental health but company doesn't look out for staff
pros: 1. Tons of positions, overtime, opportunities 2. Decent benefits 3. All departments conveniently located on same street
cons: 1. High expectations with high workloads 2. Management will side with violent/ aggressive patient over staff 3. Understaffed on crisis units and high turn over 4. Management will do multiple jobs and collect the pay for those jobs rather than offer them to qualified candidates 5. Favoritism runs rampant

review_title: Good if you're starting out bad for long term

cons: Leadership is emotional and it's not trained well Only give 3% raises so pay is bad No one teaches you how to handle clients

The doctors are the worst and border on poor ethics but you camt say nothing or the company will fire you and then tell other mental health agencies not to hire you!

pros: I enjoyed my experience and the people who worked there.

pros: Work schedule felxibility, great co-workers

pros: Okay benefits and some support. Some work life balance

pros: Weekend and night differential is a lot higher than most other places and the holiday pay/bonuses are worth it.  I could go on and on about how wonderful the other nurses and BHTs are.  The staff are like family here and watch each other’s backs.  8 hour shifts and easy to pick up overtime.
cons: Safety is often overlooked by upper management in general which causes serious problems for the floor nurses and BHTs.  Scheduled power outages that are not mentioned to staff prior, previous disgruntled employees threatening the business and management not warning staff, tools left by maintenance out in the open, policies not being reinforced, no security in a very dangerous parking area and many other safety concerns.  On top of that the place is filthy.  Cleaning staff use cheap cleansers like fabuloso and the whole place smells like urine.

review_title: Great start to my career change into non-profit
job_title: Licensed Mental Health Counselor in Tampa, FL
pros: Decent pay and some nice company functions. The medical and dental benefits were ok but I had better at previous jobs. The pre-service training or NEO (I think they called it) is some of the best and most comprehensive that I have ever received at any employer. The HR staff does a great job and made it fun. The trainings were good and some allowed to be done online. One full week of that and we were expected to be there early and on time. What followed after that week was more disorganized. .
cons: Campus is spooky at night. Inconsistent messages from different managers. Management seemed more out of touch with front line staff training and were not present enough

pros:
Dental, Vision and 401K benefits were pretty good. 
Fellow employees are lifesavers.
You get great experience.
cons:
Medical benefits aren't the best for the price.
High turnover rates
Supervisors seem disconnected from staff and when staff bring up issues they are brushed under the rug and nothing gets done
Consistently understaffed and even if you want more hours they won't give it to you. I literally would have to ask the manager on duty that day about picking up a shift either that day or the next day although unless you ask they just don't care and don't schedule people. 
Minimum requirement with shifts for PRN, management doesn't care if you have school or work another full time job.

pros: Some of the employees are nice
cons: Mini management as a counselor I can never actually use my intelligence. I always have to go to management for approval. The pay is low for case managers it just doesn't add up to the work load. Coworkers are lazy. Always short staffed. Mangers never pitch in if there's a ton of call outs or were simply swamp. Safety!! Wait there is none!! The clients can and have on multiple times hit a staff and these people are not compensated and did I forget to mention were always short staffed!! You can never move up because the manager later is so short. Honestly gracepoint cares about one thing money.

pros: Accept new grads and good Cm experience
cons:
Salary but not treated like salaries
Increase client caseload regardless if they need services or not. 
No care for staff safety. 
Work MLK day. 
You get .45 per mile when income tax mileage states the amount should be .50
Really MHC/Gracepoint you can't increase 5 cents for mileage/ per mile traveled for work.

review_title: Good experience but huge safety issues
job_title: Behavioral Health Technician in Tampa, FL
pros: Great if you don’t have experience in the medical field and are interested in working in mental health as you will see cases here you probably wouldn’t be exposed to anywhere else. There’s also a hand full of very good techs, nurses, and supervisors who genuinely care about the patients, make the unit feel like a family, and they make this job worth it. Also the majority of the patients are nice and respectful.
cons:
The biggest con of working here is you CANNOT be passive with your coworkers when it comes to patient safety. You are going to have to advocate for patients rights regularly. I truly believe some techs do not care if the patients live or die and actually enjoy engaging in take downs/physical restraints. You cannot trust the majority of your coworkers to be vigilant and actually check on the clients when doing rounds even the day after a very serious incident occurred. If you work here be prepared for coworkers to treat you poorly or gossip about you for doing your job correctly and taking patients safety seriously. You will be put in dangerous situations and situations that are a huge liability to you and whatever license you may have.
The full time staff make more than the prn staff which is odd.
The environment is very cliquey. Nurses gossiping about staff with the team lead in front of patients. Techs gossiping about patients and coworkers in front of other patients. Nurses talking to the techs in an extremely unprofessional and disrespectful manner.
Coworkers disappear from the unit for hours on overnights or are sitting in the break room not on break playing games on their phone or sitting on the patient couches watching tv when the other techs are running around working.
If you’re a conventionally attractive female get ready to be made uncomfortable and hit on by your coworkers every single day, most of which are married with children. Yikes.

review_title: Poorly run facility and the patients suffer because of it
pros: Met a few good peers who became friends. Other than that nothing and I plan to quit.
cons: Management sucks and they have huge egos when really they should check their heads. I started full-time 5 years ago and realized the benefits suck. They were also not explained well to me and my co-workers. Took a better job at a much better agency and switched to PT work. There are too many inconsistent messages from management and a lack of clarity on procedures on the unit.

pros: Health and dental benefits are okay
cons: Staff turn over is very high and morale is low. Competent staff rarely stay more than a couple of years and staff that do stay tend to have performance issues an/or a questionable past. MHC is a place for low performers to hide. Upper management will throw anyone under the bus to save themselves from their poor decision making and they are not fiscally responsible.

pros: Excellent colleagues. Particularly the behavioral health technicians. The physicians are also wonderful. M-F 8to 5.
cons: Always short staffed, the pay is low, central intake is not well put together, management does not show any appreciation whatsoever to the staff. There is a fair amount of lateral violence that goes on, along with inconsistent followings of company policies. If you're looking for an understanding company that supports it's staff, this is not the company. Staff are frequently placed in dangerous situations and their "code" alert button frequently malfunctions.

job_title: Social Rehabilitation Counselor in Boston, MA
pros: Great work, great experience, client's are great, good location and office space. Work days were interesting, fast paced and fulfilling. Good hours. Work didn't come home with you.
cons: Diversion between staff, not a team based community. Not specific training to counseling job; figure it out as you go.

job_title: Care Manager in New York, NY
pros: Nothing except that it was really close to my home in Tampa. A few patients made me laugh.
cons: I have been in the social services business for over 12 years and know what is good from other states where my wife and I have lived.  At first things were good but then I got to know my supervisor. Not worth my time and watching kids with problems suffer due to  poor management.

pros: Gracepoint gives newly graduates opportunities to get experience while making a decent amount of money.
cons: Too many chiefs and not enough Indians.  Also, there is a lack of culture and community in the workplace.

pros: It is a very laid back work environment  and the work isn't hard to complete
cons: Not the best place for brand new nurses to start out.

pros: There are plenty of opportunities to grow , as long as you work hard and don't entertain drama.
cons: Compensation could be better, but its still competitive.

pros: All shifts available. Health benefits & 401(k). Pay is very competitive.
cons: Non-profit. Raises are not guaranteed annually and are relative to the annual budget.
